candidates.title: Set finalfusion to crates.io and bump ndarray dependencies.
Extend Metadata with TrainInfo.
candidates.body:
Adds TrainInfo holding information about corpus, number of
threads, timestamps and output file.

Adds a section like this to `metadata`:
~~~
[training_info]
corpus = 'tdz-text.conll'
end_datetime = '2019-10-14 12:11:09'
n_threads = 14
output = 'throwaway'
start_datetime = '2019-10-14 12:10:57'
~~~

I'm not too sure about this particular change:

~~~Rust
fn write_model_binary(self, write: &mut W, train_info: TrainInfo) -> Result<(), Error>; 
~~~

This makes assumptions about every model being trained with a `corpus` field, `n_threads` and `output`. We could replace this with `&dyn Serialize`. What do you prefer?

candidates.title: Merge finalfrontier into a single crate
candidates.body:
Mostly moving files around. I put most of the `finalfrontier-utils` library stuff into the `io` module. The remainder is now in the `app` module.

We have a lot of crate-level symbols that should probably be removed over time (instead exposing just the submodules).

candidates.title: Add version command.
candidates.body: Could be nice to set something in CI to fail release-builds to keep the version in sync.

candidates.title: Support training with explicitly stored ngrams.
candidates.body:
Add implementation for SubwordVocab<NGramIndexer> and options for
binaries. finalfusion dependency points to GitHub to access new
features.

candidates.title: Update finalfusion dependency and remove subword module.
candidates.body:
Replace logic from subword module with implementations from
finalfusion-rust. The updated dependency requires a bump of the
minimal rust version to 1.32.

Part of what I described in #61, I ditched the idea of wrapping full `finalfusion` vocabs because we'd collect indices for every single word in the corpus, even if it is actually OOV.

The subword module & indexer(s) from `finalfusion` still come in handy to implement the `NGramVocab`. Also, if we ever wanted to offer the fastText hashing function, that'd be easily done now.

candidates.title: Update finalfusion dependency to 0.7.1 to ensure norms storage
Update dependencies.
candidates.body: To avoid accidental, automatic, updates in other PRs.

candidates.title: Add support for training without subwords.
candidates.body: Once #53 lands, this should be the last required bit to enable training without subwords.

candidates.title: Update license to the Blue Oak Model License 1.0.0
candidates.body: Acked by Sebastian Pütz and Nianheng Wu.

candidates.title: Change Vocab and Trainers to prepare non-subword training. [Traits, take2]
candidates.body:
Yet another approach. This time based on two traits that the index types implement. The main ideas behind this iteration are:
* `SGD` and  `TrainModel` should be agnostic to the index type they receive.
* indexing should be resolved inside `Vocab` and `Trainer`. 
* `SGD` only needs an iterator over the indices, `TrainModel` additionally requires `.len()`. 

The relevant traits are:
* `IndexIterator`, providing `.iter()` over the indices and `.len()`, implemented on references of the index types.
* `WordIdx`, providing `.word_idx()` to get the word idx and `.from_word_idx()` to construct a variant with only a single index.

Integration of the new traits:
* `TrainModel`'s input lookup methods now take `impl IndexIterator` as argument.
*  `TrainIterFrom` has an associated `Focus` type, `update_sentence` places bounds for `&TrainIterFrom::Focus: IndexIterator`
* `NegativeSamplingSGD` now takes `impl IntoIterator<Item=u64>` as argument for inputs.

The indexing types and traits reside in their own `idx` module, since `vocab` started to get quite crowded.

candidates.title: Update to finalfusion 0.6 and store embedding norms
candidates.body: I still have to do some testing, but this should store the norms.

candidates.title: Update the documentation links and README
Add projectivization switch.
candidates.body:
Adds option to projectivize dependency graphs before training. This is all a bit messier than I hoped. With how the binaries are structured at this point, I couldn't come up with a nice abstraction. For now we could stick with some wrapper struct holding an optional projectivizer: ```Rust struct SentenceIter { inner: Reader, projectivizer: Option

, } ``` and implement `Iterator` for it. There's some ugliness in the `do_work` method because `HeadProjectivizer` doesn't derive `Copy + Clone`.

candidates.title: Add AppStructs for Depembeds and SkipGram.
candidates.body:
Rather light weight changes with lots of lines.

While implementing the `ff-deps` binary I realized I didn't really like the same `AppBuilder` for both training types. I defined `SkipGramApp` and `DepembedsApp` structs that handle all clap-related business and construct all the required configs. The required configs and values can be accessed through getter methods.

Next step after this PR is the actual binary, then clean up (there were some incorrect docs somewhere in the `dep` module)  and we should be ready to release.

candidates.title: Migrate to Rust 2018
candidates.body:
We were still implicitly on Rust 2015, while at the same time using
post-2018 features. So:

- Switch to Rust 2018
- Also do CI builds on Rust 1.31

The motivation to also test builds against 1.31 is that this is the
first Rust version that supports 2018. Later versions have changes
that are not strictly Rust 2018. I want to stick to 1.31/2018 as the
lowest common denominator for a while, since Linux distributions are
sometimes trailing in Rust versions.

repo.name: finalfrontier
repo.description: Context-sensitive word embeddings with subwords. In Rust.
